facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 976 and 977 of 1964 are appeals from the judgment and decree dated March 26, 1964 of the Patna High Court in Election Appeals Nos. 8 and 10 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 976 and 977 of 1964. Appeals from the judgment and decree dated March 26, 1964 of the Patna High Court in Election Appeals Nos. 8 and 10 of 1963. B. Agarwala, Jagdish Panday, Chinta Subbarao, M. Rajagopalan and B.P. Jha, for the appellant,  In both the appeals .

facts.text: Kedar Pandey (appellant) and Narain Bikram Sah (respondent, called Narain Raja) were contesting candidates in 1962 election for Ramnagar Constituency in Champaran district for Bihar Legislative Assembly, on Congress and Swatantra Party tickets respectively.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Kedar Pandey and the respondent--Narain Bikram Sah hereinafter called Narain Raja  were the companytesting candidates in the year 1962 on behalf of the Congress and Swatantra Party respectively for the election to Bihar Legislative Assembly from Ramnagar Constituency in the district of Champaran.

facts.text: Nomination papers of Kedar Pandey, Narain Raja, Parmeshwar Prasad Roy and Suleman Khan were accepted by Returning Officer on January 22, 1962 without objection.

anchor.surface_text: The numberination papers of the appellant and the respondent and two others--Parmeshwar Prasad Roy and Suleman Khan-were accepted by the Returning Officer without any objection on January 22, 1962. Later on the two candidates--Parmeshwar Prasad Roy and Suleman Khan--withdrew their candidatures.

facts.text: Parmeshwar Prasad Roy and Suleman Khan withdrew their candidatures after nominations.

anchor.surface_text: Later on the two candidates--Parmeshwar Prasad Roy and Suleman Khan--withdrew their candidatures. After the poll the respondent, Narain Raja was declared elected as member of the Bihar Legislative Assembly by majority of valid votes.

facts.text: Narain Raja was declared elected as member of Bihar Legislative Assembly from Ramnagar Constituency after the poll.

anchor.surface_text: After the poll the respondent, Narain Raja was declared elected as member of the Bihar Legislative Assembly by majority of valid votes. On April 11, 1962 Kedar Pandey filed an election petition challenging the election of the respondent.

facts.text: Kedar Pandey filed election petition on April 11, 1962 challenging Narain Raja's election on ground of not being qualified under Art. 173 as not a citizen of India.

anchor.surface_text: On April 11, 1962 Kedar Pandey filed an election petition challenging the election of the respondent. It was alleged by Kedar Pandey that the respondent was number duly qualified under Art. 173 of the Constitution of India to be a candidate for election as he was number a citizen of India.

facts.text: Petitioner alleged respondent, parents and grandparents born in Nepal, related to royal family, owned land and house in Barewa, Nepal.

anchor.surface_text: According to Kedar Pandey the respondent, his parents and grand-parents were all born in Nepal and, therefore, on the date of the election, the respondent-Narain Raja--was number qualified to be chosen to fill the Assembly seat for which he had been declared to have been elected.

facts.text: Respondent contested that he is Indian citizen, lived in India since birth, resident of Ramnagar, Champaran, not Barewa, born in Banaras.

anchor.surface_text: The election petition was companytested by the respondent who said that he was an Indian citizen and there was numberdisqualification incurred under Art. 173 of the Constitution. The further case of the respondent was that he had lived in India since his birth and that he was a resident of Ramnagar in the district of Champaran and number of Barewa in Nepal.

facts.text: Election Tribunal held Narain Raja not citizen of India, not qualified under Art. 173, election void, but refused declaration for Kedar Pandey.

anchor.surface_text: Upon these rival companytentions it was held by the Tribunal that the respondent Narain Raja--was number a citizen of India and, therefore, was number qualified under Art. 173 of the Constitution for being chosen to fill a seat in the Bihar Legislative Assembly. The Tribunal, therefore, declared that the election of the respondent was void.

facts.text: Both parties appealed Tribunal's judgment to Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Both the appellant and the respondent preferred separate appeals against the judgment of the Election Tribunal to the High Court of Judicature at Patna.

facts.text: Patna High Court set aside Tribunal judgment, upheld Narain Raja's election, found born in Banaras on October 10, 1918, living in India from 1939 to 1949 and after, acquired domicile of choice in India before 1949 under Art. 5(a) and (c).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in appeal set aside the judgment of the Tribunal and upheld the election of the respondent Narain Raja. The High Court found, on examination of the evidence, that Narain Raja, the respondent before us, was born in Banaras on October 10, 1918 and that the respondent was living in India from 1939 right upto 1949 and even thereafter.

facts.text: Ramnagar estate originally belonged to Shri Prahlad Sen, then to Mohan Vikram Sah (Mohan Raja), then Rani Chhatra Kumari Devi, then Rama Raja (father of respondent).

anchor.surface_text: The history of the family of Narain Raja is closely companynected with the history of Ramnagar estate. It appears that Ramnagar estate in the district of Champaran in Bihar originally belonged to. Shri Prahlad Sen after whose death the estate came into the possession of Shri Mohan Vikram Sah, popularly known as Mohan Raja.

facts.text: Mohan Raja died in 1912, executed will in 1904 in favour of wife Rani Chhatra Kumari Devi.

anchor.surface_text: by virtue of a will executed by Mohan Raja in the year 1904 in favour of his wife Rani Chhatra Kumari Devi the Rani became entitled to the Ramnagar estate on the death of Mohan Raja  which took place in 1912 , in preference to the adopted son Rama Raja

facts.text: Rani Chhatra Kumari Devi died in 1937, after which Rama Raja took possession of Ramnagar estate.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Rani L P D 5SCI--12 Chhatra Kumari Devi in 1937 Rama Raja came into the possession of the Ramnagar estate.

facts.text: Partition suit No. 40 of 1942 filed on September 29, 1942 by Rama Raja and sons including respondent; preliminary decree April 16, 1943; final decree May 22, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: There is evidence that Rama Raja died in Bombay and his dead-body was cremated in Banaras. It is also in evidence that during the lifetime of Rama Raja there was a partition suit in the year 1942--No. 40 of 1942--for the partition of the properties of the Ramnagar estate among Rama Raja and his sons including the respondent. This suit was filed on September 29, 1942

facts.text: Petitioner claims Narain Raja born at Barewa in Nepal; respondent claims born at Banaras.

anchor.surface_text: In order to prove his case the appellant examined two witnesses---Sheonath Tewari W. 18  and N.D. Pathak  P.W. 15 . The High Court held that their evidence was acceptable. There was also a plaint  Ex. 8  produced on behalf the appellant to show that Narain Raja was born at Barewa.

facts.text: High Court found Narain Raja born in Banaras on October 10, 1918.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found, on examination of the evidence, that Narain Raja, the respondent before us, was born in Banaras on October 10, 1918 and that the respondent was living in India from 1939 right upto 1949 and even thereafter.

facts.text: Both High Court and Tribunal found Narain Raja ordinarily resident in India for 5 years preceding commencement of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: in view of the companycurrent findings of both the High Court and the Tribunal that for a period of 5 years preceding the companymencement of the Constitution Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in the territory of India.

facts.text: Narain Raja educated in Calcutta 1934-1938, lived in Ramnagar from 1938, continued after father's death 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The following facts have been either admitted by the parties found to be established in this case. Narain Raja was educated in Calcutta from 1934 to 1938. From the year 1938 onwards Narain Raja lived in Ramnagar.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Narain Raja acquired domicile of choice in India before end of 1949, citizen under Art. 5.

anchor.surface_text: Taking all the events and circumstances of Narain Rajas life into account we are satisfied that long before the end of 1949 which is the material time under Art. 5 of the Constitution, Narain Raja had acquired a domicil of choice in India.

facts.text: Rama Raja died in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: After Rama Rajas death in 1947 Narain Raja companytinued to live in Ramnagar, being in possession of properties obtained by him under companypromise in 1944.

facts.text: Narain Raja obtained Indian Passport on March 23, 1949 describing him as Indian by birth and nationality, address Ramnagar.

anchor.surface_text: It is also important to numberice that Narain Raja had obtained Indian Passport dated March 23, 1949 from Lucknow issued by the Governor-General of India and he is described in that Passport as Indian by birth and nationality and his address is given as Ramnagar of Champaran district.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds requirements of Art. 5(c) satisfied as ordinarily resident in India for 5 years before Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We have already referred to the finding of the High Court that Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in India for 5 years immediately preceding the time when Art. 5 of the Constitution came into force.

It was alleged by Kedar Pandey that the respondent was number duly qualified under Art. 173 of the Constitution of India to be a candidate for election as he was number a citizen of India. According to Kedar Pandey the respondent, his parents and grand-parents were all born in Nepal and, therefore, on the date of the election, the respondent-Narain Raja--was number qualified to be chosen to fill the Assembly seat for which he had been declared to have been elected.

concepts.unlisted_description: Qualification to be chosen to fill a seat in State Legislative Assembly requires citizenship of India

The Tribunal, therefore, declared that the election of the respondent was void.

anchor.surface_text: The crucial question for determination in this case, therefore. is whether Narain Raja had acquired the domicil of choice in India. The law on the topic is well-established but the difficulty is found in its application to varying companybination of circumstances in each case.

anchor.surface_text: The law attributes to every person at birth a domicil which is called a domicil of origin. This domicil may be changed and a new domicil, which is called a domicil of choice, acquired but the two kinds of domicil differ in one respect.

concepts.interpretation: Determined by domicile of father (or mother for posthumous) at birth; continues until clearly abandoned

The state of mind, or animus manendi, which is required demands that the person whose domicil is the object of the inquiry should have formed a fixed and settled purpose of making his principal or sole permanent home

anchor.surface_text: It is also well-established that the onus of proving that a domicil has been chosen in substitution for the domicil of origin lies upon those who assert that the domicil of origin has been lost. The domicil of origin companytinues unless a fixed and settled intention of abandoning the first domicil and aquiring another as the sole domicil is clearly shown

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that the, only intention required for a proof of a change of domicil is an intention of permanent residence. In other words, what is required to be established is that the person who is alleged to have changed his domicil of origin has voluntarily fixed the habitation of himself and his family in the new companyntry

issues.text: The main question arising for decision in this case is whether the High Court was right in its conclusion that the respondent-Narain Raja--was a citizen of India under Art. 5 of the Constitution of India on the material date.

anchor.surface_text: On these findings the High Court took the view that Narain Raja was duly qualified for being elected to the Bihar Legislative Assembly and the election petition filed by the appellant--Kedar Pandey--should be dismissed. The main question arising for decision in this case is whether the High Court was right in its conclusion that the respondent-Narain Raja--was a citizen of India under Art. 5 of the Constitution of India on the material date.

issues.text: the only question remaining for consideration is the question whether Narain Raja had his domicil in the territory of India at the material time.

anchor.surface_text: We do not, however, think it necessary to express any concluded opinion on this question of fact but proceed to decide the case the assumption that Narain Raja was not born in the territory ,of India, in the year 1918. The reason is that the place of birth of Narain Raja has lost its importance in this case in view of the concurrent findings of both the High Court and the Tribunal that for a period of 5 years preceding the commencement of the Constitution Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in the territory of India. Therefore the requirement of Art. 5 c  of the Constitution is fulfilled. Mr. Aggarwala on behalf of the appellant did not challenge this finding of the High Court. It is. therefore, manifest that the requirement of Art. 5 c  of the Constitution has been established and the only question remaining for consideration is the question whether Narain Raja had his domicil in the territory of India at the material time.

issues.text: The crucial question for determination in this case, therefore. is whether Narain Raja had acquired the domicil of choice in India.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court therefore, proceeded upon the assumption that Narain Raja had his domicil of origin in Nepal and examined the evidence to find out whether Narain Raja had deliberately chosen the domicil of choice in India in substitution for the domicil of origin. The crucial question for determination in this case, therefore. is whether Narain Raja had acquired the domicil of choice in India. The law on the topic is well-established but the difficulty is found in its application to varying combination of circumstances in each case.

issues.text: whether the respondent was not duly qualified under Art. 173 of the Constitution of India to be a candidate for election as he was not a citizen of India.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged by Kedar Pandey that the respondent was not duly qualified under Art. 173 of the Constitution of India to be a candidate for election as he was not a citizen of India. According to Kedar Pandey the respondent, his parents and grand-parents were all born in Nepal and, therefore, on the date of the election, the respondent-Narain Raja--was not qualified to be chosen to fill the Assembly seat for which he had been declared to have been elected.

arguments.claim: The respondent was not duly qualified under Art. 173 of the Constitution of India to be a candidate for election as he was not a citizen of India, since he, his parents and grandparents were all born in Nepal.

anchor.surface_text: On April 11, 1962 Kedar Pandey filed an election petition challenging the election of the respondent. It was alleged by Kedar Pandey that the respondent was not duly qualified under Art. 173 of the Constitution of India to be a candidate for election as he was not a citizen of India. According to Kedar Pandey the respondent, his parents and grand-parents were all born in Nepal and, therefore, on the date of the election, the respondent-Narain Raja--was not qualified to be chosen to fill the Assembly seat for which he had been declared to have been elected.

arguments.claim: The respondent is an Indian citizen with no disqualification under Art. 173, having lived in India since birth, resident of Ramnagar in Champaran district, not Barewa in Nepal, and born in Banaras.

arguments.claim: The respondent Narain Raja was not a citizen of India and therefore not qualified under Art. 173 for election to Bihar Legislative Assembly; his election is void.

The Tribunal, therefore, declared that the election of the respondent was void.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court set aside Tribunal judgment on examination of evidence, finding citizenship under Art. 5; SC upheld.

arguments.claim: Narain Raja was born in Banaras on October 10, 1918, lived in India from 1939 to 1949 and thereafter, acquired domicile of choice in India before 1949, hence citizen under Art. 5(a) and (c), qualified under Art. 173.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in appeal set aside the judgment of the Tribunal and upheld the election of the respondent Narain Raja. The High Court found, on examination of the evidence, that Narain Raja, the respondent before us, was born in Banaras on October 10, 1918 and that the respondent was living in India from 1939 right upto 1949 and even thereafter.

arguments.court_reasoning: SC satisfied Narain Raja acquired domicile of choice before end of 1949 and ordinary resident 5 years; High Court conclusion correct.

arguments.claim: High Court was not justified in holding Narain Raja born in Banaras in 1918; he was born at Barewa in Nepal, proved by witnesses Sheonath Tewari (W18), N.D. Pathak (PW15), and plaint Ex.8.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant Mr. Aggarwala put forward the argument that the High Court was not justified in holding that Narain Raja was born in Banaras in the year 1918. According the case of the appellant Narain Raja was born at a place called Barewa in Nepal. In order to prove his case the appellant examined two witnesses---Sheonath Tewari W. 18  and N.D. Pathak  P.W. 15 .

arguments.claim: Absence of birth record in Banaras municipal registers Ex.2 series for 1918 and ongoing litigation with Rani indicate Rama Raja not living at Ramnagar house, improbable birth in Banaras.

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted by Mr. Aggarwala that there were two circumstances which indicate that the respondent could not have been born at Banaras In the first place, it was pointed out, the municipal registers of Banaras for the year 1918---Ex. 2 series--did not mention the birth of the respondent.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: arain Raja had acquired the domicil of choice in India. The law on the topic is well-established but

arguments.court_reasoning: House at Mamurganj not within municipality limits in 1918; omission insignificant.

arguments.claim: Place of birth immaterial; assume Narain Raja not born in India in 1918, but concurrent findings of High Court and Tribunal establish ordinary residence in India for 5 years preceding Constitution, satisfying Art. 5(c); unchallenged by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We do not, however, think it necessary to express any concluded opinion on this question of fact but proceed to decide the case the assumption that Narain Raja was not born in the territory ,of India, in the year 1918. The reason is that the place of birth of Narain Raja has lost its importance in this case in view of the concurrent findings of both the High Court and the Tribunal that for a period of 5 years preceding the commencement of the Constitution Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in the territory of India.

arguments.claim: Domicile of origin of Mohan Raja was in India (acquired choice after inheriting Ramnagar Raj, married Ranis in Ramnagar); at adoption of Rama Raja in 1903, Rama acquired Indian domicile by fiction as son.

anchor.surface_text: Upon this question it was argued before the High Court on behalf of the respondent that the domicil of origin of Mohan Raja may have been in Nepal but he had acquired a domicile of choice in India after inheriting Ramnagar Raj from his maternal grandfather Prahlad Sen. It was said that Mohan Raja had settled down in India and had married all his 4 Ranis in Ramnagar.

arguments.claim: Rama Raja acquired domicile of choice in India upon taking possession of Ramnagar estate after Rani Chhatra Kumari Devi's death in 1937, remaining in possession until death in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended in the alternative that whatever may have been Rama Rajas domicil before 1937 when Rani Chhatra Kumari Devi died, Rama Raja acquired a domicil of choice in India when he came to India on the death of Rani Chhatra Kumari Devi. It was also stated on behalf of the respondent that Rama Raja remained in possession of the Ramnagar estate until his death in 1947.

arguments.claim: Domicile of choice requires physical residence in new country with animus manendi (fixed settled purpose of permanent home); domicile of origin continues unless clearly abandoned; onus on party asserting change.

anchor.surface_text: The crucial question for determination in this case, therefore. is whether Narain Raja had acquired the domicil of choice in India. The law on the topic is well-established but the difficulty is found in its application to varying combination of circumstances in each case. The law attributes to every person at birth a domicil which is called a domicil of origin.

arguments.claim: Narain Raja acquired domicile of choice in India before end of 1949, as shown by residence in Ramnagar from 1938, education in Calcutta 1934-38, partition suit 1942-44, property management, acquisitions, Indian passport 1949 declaring Indian by birth, minimal Nepal ties; post-1949 conduct relevant.

anchor.surface_text: The following facts have been either admitted by the parties found to be established in this case. Narain Raja was educated in Calcutta from 1934 to 1938. From the year 1938 onwards Narain Raja lived in Ramnagar. After Rama Rajas death in 1947 Narain Raja continued to live in Ramnagar, being in possession of properties obtained by him under compromise in 1944.

arguments.claim: Ownership of minor property in Nepal (43 bighas per Ex.10c khatian 1960) shows no intention of permanent residence in India.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant Mr. Aggarwala suggested that there were two reasons to show that Narain Raja had no intention of making his domicil of choice in India. Reference was made, in this context, to Ex. 10 c  which is a khatian prepared in 1960. showing certain properties standing in the name of Narain Raja and his brothers in Nepal.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is ties with Nepal. There was evidence in this ease that Narain Rajas eider brother Shiv Bikram Sah has left male issues. For the reasons expressed, w

arguments.court_reasoning: Minor area compared to extensive Indian properties post-1944 partition; property inherited from grandmother via father, proved by Sanad Ex.AA.

arguments.claim: Use of title 'Sri 5' by Narain Raja and Rama Raja indicates intention to retain ties to Nepal royal family and possible claim to throne.

anchor.surface_text: It was also pointed out on behalf of the appellant that Narain Raja, and before him Rama Raja, had insisted upon designating themselves Sri 5, indicating that they belonged to the royal family of Nepal It was argued on behalf of the appellant that Narain Raja had clung tenaciously to the title of Sri 5, thereby indicating the intention of not relinquishing the claim to the throne of Nepal.

arguments.court_reasoning: Title due to pride and sentimental attachment to ancestry; no substance as succession by primogeniture, elder brother has male issues, no real hope for throne.

arguments.claim: Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in India for 5 years immediately preceding commencement of Constitution, satisfying Art. 5(c).

anchor.surface_text: We have already referred to the finding of the High Court that Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in India for 5 years immediately preceding the time when Art. 5 of the Constitution came into force.

holdings.text: The requirement of Art. 5(c) of the Constitution is fulfilled as Narain Raja was ordinarily resident in the territory of India for 5 years preceding the commencement of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Aggarwala on behalf of the appellant did not challenge this finding of the High Court. It is therefore, manifest that the requirement of Art. 5 c of the Constitution has been established and the only question remaining for consideration is the question whether Narain Raja had his domicil in the territory of India at the material time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings of High Court and Tribunal unchallenged by appellant; place of birth immaterial.

holdings.text: Narain Raja had acquired a domicile of choice in India long before the end of 1949, the material time under Art. 5 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Taking all the events and circumstances of Narain Rajas life into account we are satisfied that long before the end of 1949 which is the material time under Art. 5 of the Constitution, Narain Raja had acquired a domicil of choice in India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Residence in Ramnagar from 1938, education in Calcutta, partition suit and property management 1942-44, Indian passport 1949 declaring Indian nationality, minimal Nepal ties; animus manendi proved by facts.

holdings.text: Narain Raja had formed the deliberate intention of making his home in India with the intention of permanently establishing himself and his family there; the requisite animus manendi has been proved and the finding of the High Court is correct.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of domicile law to facts of long-term residence, property ownership, family settlement, and declarations like passport; onus discharged.

holdings.text: Narain Raja had acquired domicile of choice in India when Art. 5 of the Constitution came into force.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed, we hold that Narain Raja had acquired domicil of choice in India when Art. 5 of the Constitution came into force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative events prior to 1949 establish fixed intention to reside permanently; rejects counter-arguments on Nepal property and title as insignificant.

holdings.text: The requirements of Art. 5(c) of the Constitution are satisfied and the High Court rightly reached the conclusion that Narain Raja was a citizen of India at the relevant time.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Domicile of choice plus ordinary residence satisfy Art. 5(a) and (c); thus qualified under Art. 173.

holdings.text: The only intention required for proof of change of domicile is an intention of permanent residence; voluntarily fixing habitation in new country with present intention of making it permanent home.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Udny v. Udny and Doucet v. Geoghegan; distinguishes Moorhouse v. Lord as going beyond domicile.

holdings.text: Conduct and acts after the relevant time are relevant to determine intention at the material time, assigning relative weight.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Supported by In re Grove; standard evidentiary rule.

precedents.cited_proposition: domicil of origin continues unless a fixed and settled intention of abandoning the first domicil and acquiring another as the sole domicil is clearly shown

anchor.surface_text: In Munro v. Munro 2  Lord Cottonham states the rule as follows The domicil of origin must prevail until the party has number only acquired another, but has manifested and carried into execution an intention of abandoning his former domicil, and acquiring another as his sole domicil.

precedents.cited_proposition: domicil of origin must prevail until the party has not only acquired another, but has manifested and carried into execution an intention of abandoning his former domicil and acquiring another as his sole domicil
precedents.cited_holding: Lord Cottenham states the rule as follows

anchor.surface_text: In Aikman v. Aikman 1 , Lord Campbell has discussed the question of the effect on domicil of an intention to return to the native country, where such intention is attributable to an undefined and remote contingency. He said If a man is settled in a foreign country,

precedents.cited_proposition: effect on domicil of an intention to return to the native country on undefined and remote contingency

anchor.surface_text: Moorhouse v. Lord 2  in which it was held that in order to lose a domicil of origin, and to acquire a new domicil, a man must intend quatenus in illo exuere patriam and there must be a change of nationality, that is natural allegiance R is number enough for him to take a house in the new country,

precedents.cited_proposition: to lose a domicil of origin and acquire a new domicil, a man must intend to exuere patriam and there must be a change of nationality

anchor.surface_text: Udny v. Udny 3  which decision is the leading authority on what constitute a domicil of choice taking the place of a domicil of origin. It is there pointed out by Lord Westbury that the expressions used in Moorhouse v Lord , as to the intent exuere patriam, are calculated to mislead, and go beyond the question of domicil.

precedents.cited_proposition: domicil of choice is a conclusion or inference from voluntarily fixing sole or chief residence in a place with intention of continuing indefinitely; expressions in Moorhouse about exuere patriam misleading
precedents.cited_holding: Domicil of choice is a conclusion or inference which the law derives from the fact of a man fixing voluntarily his sole or chief residence...

anchor.surface_text: Doucet v. Geoghegan  1  the Court of Appeal decided that the testator had acquired an English domicil and one of the main facts relied on was that he had twice married in England in a manner not conforming to the formalities which are required by the French Law for the legalisation of marriages of Frenchmen in a foreign country.

precedents.cited_proposition: acquisition of English domicile based on facts like marriages in England not conforming to French formalities, bringing up children, making will

anchor.surface_text: Udny Undy 3  and Doucet v. Geoghegan 1  represent the correct law with regard to change of domicil of origin. We are of the view that the, only intention required for a proof of a change of domicil is an intention of permanent residence.

precedents.cited_proposition: correct law with regard to change of domicil of origin

anchor.surface_text: Doucet v. Geoghegan 1  represent the correct law with regard to change of domicil of origin. We are of the view that the, only intention required for a proof of a change of domicil is an intention of permanent residence. In other words, what is required to be established is that the person who is alleged to have changed his domicil of origin has voluntarily fixed the habitation of himself and his family in the new country,

precedents.cited_proposition: correct law with regard to change of domicil of origin

precedents.citation: In re Grove Vaucher v. The Solicitor to the Treasury

anchor.surface_text: Treasury 1  in which the domicil of one Marc Thomegay in 1744 was at issue and various facts and circumstances after 1744 were considered to be relevant. At page 242 of the report Lopes, L.J. has stated The domicil of an independent person is constituted by the factum of residence in a country, and the animus manendi, that is, the intention to reside in that country for an indefinite period.

precedents.case_name: In re Grove; Vaucher v Solicitor to the Treasury
precedents.cited_proposition: course of conduct and acts before, at, and after the relevant time are relevant to determine intention at a given time

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Aggarwala on behalf of the appellant did not challenge this finding of the High Court.
